_description: The Chester Plays: twenty-five plays and (in some MSS) the Banns of Proclamation

Bod175.First Lines:
Ego sum Alpha et Oprimus et novissimusIt is my will it
                    shalbe soo…
Bod175.Last Lines:
…Therefore excuse you withowten wereI may not well I
                    wise
Bod175.Attributed Title:
The tanners plays being the ff of the wholle booke (f. 3); Pagina prima
                        de Celi Angelorum et Inferni specium Creatione (f. 3); Finis. Deo
                    Gratias. This is the last of all the xxiiijor pageantes or playes played by the
                    xxiiijor craftes men of the Cittie of Chester written in the yere of our Lorde
                    god 1604. And in the second yere of the Reigne of king James by the grace of god
                    of England ffrauns and Ireland and defender of the faith and of the Realme of
                    England the xxxvij-th per me Gulielmum Bedford (f. 176)
Bod175.Facsimiles:
Lumiansky,  R. M.,  and  David Mills.  
             “Introduction.” 
             The Chester Mystery Cycle: A Facsimile of MS. Bodley 175.
Leeds Texts and Monographs, Medieval Drama Facsimiles
         1. Leeds: University of Leeds School of English, 1973.

BLAdd10305.First Lines:
Ego sum alpha et o primus et N…If is my will yt shoulde be
                    soe…
BLAdd10305.Note:
A.D. 1592. First line is partial, due to damage to the first folio of
                    the manuscript. The last two lines are almost completely destroyed in the
                    manuscript, so are omitted from this record.
BLAdd10305.Editions:
Wright,  Thomas. 
             The Chester Plays.
         2 vols. London: Shakespeare Society, 1843, 1847.

BLAdd27945.First Lines: Ego sum alpha et [N]Primus et novissimus…
BLAdd27945.Last Lines:
…Therefore excuse you withouten wereI maye not well I
                    wysse

BLHar1944.First Lines: Reuerend Lordes & Ladyes allþat at this tyme heare assembled be…
BLHar1944.Last Lines: …All þat with quiett myndeCan be contented to taryeBe heare on whetson MondayThen begineth þe storye

BLHar2150.First Lines: Lordinges Royall and Reuere allLouely ladies that here be leall…
BLHar2150.Last Lines: …Saue all this goodely companyAnd kepe you nyght and day
BLHar2150.Note: Banns only. Preceded on f. 85v by list of the crafts of Chester, headed “These be the craftys of the Citie the whiche craftys bere the charge of the pagyns in Pley of corpus christi,” and on 86 a prose introduction.

ManCent82211.First Lines:
…Yee Lordes and Ladyes so lufle [ ]Yee kempes yee known
                    knyghtes [ ]Hareken all hethar wardes my hestes to [ ]ffor I am most
                    fayrest & fresshest to f[ ]…
ManCent82211.Last Lines:
…[ ] thonder and earth began to quakeThereof am I
                    adredCayphasAnd this was yesterday about[e] none…
ManCent82211.Note:
Three and a half stanzas of ‘Resurrection’ only: 25 lines of
                    speech of Pylate and a speech of Cayphas, of which lines toward end are mostly
                    illegible due to damp and wear.

HunHM2.First Lines:
Ego sum alpha et ooprimus et novissimus It is my will
                    it shoulde be soehit is yt was it shalbe thus…
HunHM2.Last Lines:
…therfore excuse you withowten wereI may not well I
                    wysse
HunHM2.Attributed Title:
This ys the laste of all the xxiiiitie pageantes and playes
                    played by the xxiiites craftesmen of the Cyttie of Chester wrytten in
                    the yeare of our lord god 1591 and in the xxxiiiith yeare of the
                    reigne of our sovereigne Ladye queene Elizabeth whom god preserve for ever Amen.
                    finis. By me Edward Gregorie scholler at Bunburye the yeare of our lord god 1591
                    (f. 150v)
